fields.title_en: Our ongoing journey from REST to GraphQL on Android
fields.title_ja: Our ongoing journey from REST to GraphQL on Android
fields.description_en:
Here is the story of an ongoing migration... and what a migration! This journey moving from our REST API to the GraphQL one is a long run with much coordination across all tech teams.
 

 This return of experience will focus on how we are dealing with this transition on Android where Retrofit coexists with Apollo, how we synchronized with backend teams to keep our GraphQL schemas up-to-date or how we are dealing with our authentication stack with Apollo Kotlin, or the issues we faced and much more.
 

 Buckle up! Relax! The journey is just starting üöú
fields.target_audience: People interested in knowing more about GraphQL and/or want to move from REST to GraphQL on Android using the Apollo Library.

fields.title_en: Create Android/iOS apps with Jetpack Compose
fields.description_en:
An alpha version of Compose for iOS was released at KotlinConf 2023.
 This means that both Android and iOS apps can now be developed using Jetpack Compose.
 The goal of this session is to try making an Android/iOS app with Jetpack Compose by implementing an app with a simple API communication.


 Please note that Compose for iOS is still in alpha version as of 2023/04/25, so the content of the session may be subject to change.

fields.title_en: Android Open-source repositories 101: Everything you always wanted to know
fields.title_ja: Android Open-source repositories 101: Everything you always wanted to know
fields.description_en:
Open-source repositories are a critical part of the Android development ecosystem. They allow developers to easily access and integrate third-party libraries and tools into their projects, saving time and effort. However, managing open-source repositories can be challenging, especially when it comes to issues such as automation, bots, and licensing. 
 

 In this session, we will provide a comprehensive overview of open-source repositories for Android developers, covering everything from setting up a repository to maintaining and contributing to it. Come here to learn how to maintain and work with Android Open-Source repositories in 2023!
fields.target_audience: Android developers interested in releasing and managing open-source repositories.

fields.title_en: Automate and generate. KSP feat KCP against the boilerplate in practice
fields.title_ja: Automate and generate. KSP feat KCP against the boilerplate in practice
fields.description_en:
KSP (Kotlin Symbol Processing) is an API from Google and recommended approach to be used instead of KAPT. Using KSP we can write annotation processors to reduce boilerplate, solve cross-cutting concerns and generate code for different purposes. Another way to optimize the code is to use Kotlin compiler plugins.
 In my talk I would to like to show how to create own plugins and processors and use them in such cases as wrapping request to usecases or managing module configuration
fields.target_audience: Intermediate level, middle and senior developers Android or KMM

fields.title_en: How to deal with exceptions on layered architecture of medium apps
fields.description_en:
Exception handling becomes more complex as applications grow in scale and more systems cooperate.


 Just like architecture, if appropriate policies are not established for the entire project, the user experience may be impaired due to lack of appropriate user feedbacks - and developers themselves may be affected. Indeed, a consequence of having to maintain code with low readability, investigate user complaints and so on, is that it can hinder the essential value creation for developers.



 In this session, I would like to explain about exception handling in layered architecture for mid-size applications, and share the policy adopted in the mid-size application in which I am actually involved at work.


  The following is what is planned for the session.


 ‚ñ† History of exception handling
 Changes at a language specification level (from checking to unchecking exceptions due to transitioning from Java to Kotlin language)


 ‚ñ†  General approach to exception handling
 - Dealing with unchecked exceptions
 - Handling error results


 ‚ñ† Exception handling policy adopted by a real-world application
 Exception class as a domain model (custom Exception)
 Provide error codes through a common interface
  - Static error codes
  - Dynamic error codes
 Hierarchical classification of custom exceptions with sealed class
 Error handling per UI layer concern
 - Handling exceptions depending on the behavior of the exception


 ‚ñ† Types of error handling
 Feedback for user-intended behavior
 Feedback with asynchronous timing
 Error handling for events that are not of the user's concern


 ‚ñ† User feedback for exceptions
 Presentation of event, cause, and action

You may not often have the need to process large amounts of data at high speed in an Android application. However, when it is necessary, have you ever seen or heard people say, "It is slow because it is using Kotlin (Java), it should be written in C/C++"? In some ways, that opinion may be correct. However, I think that in many cases, this opinion is based on a vague image that JVM languages are slow, even though sufficient tuning has not been done.


 It is possible to write sufficiently fast processing even in Kotlin. Readability does not have to be sacrificed either: readability and speed can go hand in hand.
 However, because Kotlin is a high-level language, it is difficult to see the cost at runtime, and a little know-how is required to achieve a high-performance implementation.


 In this session, I will demonstrate with actual examples how to achieve high speed processing in Android applications while using Kotlin, what to watch out for, what slows down processing, and finally how to attain both code readability and high speed.

fields.title_en: A small leak can sink a great ship
fields.title_ja: A small leak can sink a great ship
fields.description_en:
Memory plays an important role in making an Android application famous. Lesser the memory requirement, the application will run faster on the Android ecosystem.
 Android ecosystem tries to keep as many applications in memory as possible to enable quicker & smoother switching between applications and tasks, keeping a device feel ‚Äúsnappy‚Äù to the end user.
 So, the lesser the memory requirement, the faster the app will run on a device. 
 

 So to enhance the user experience and to strengthen the Android ecosystem, memory pressure will be directly proportional to app stability, thus bringing memory leaks into the picture.
 

 High memory leaks lead to sluggy apps or skipping frames during its execution or even termination of your application in the middle of critical work. And finally, you may end up with a crash report that doesn't appear to be memory related.
 

 Most developers do not focus on memory leaks till they are noticeable due to ANR / Out of memory errors, at which point they require a major rewrite. During development and testing, using tools such as LeakCanary can help you detect and resolve memory leaks.
 

 But now it's time to explore LeakCanary 2 & Integration with a dashboard like Firebase to analyse memory pitfalls for apps. Just a simplified way to detect memory leaks during development and testing automation. 
 How to prioritise bugs by the collection of all memory leaks in a dashboard (Not all bugs are worth fixing. Only fix the ones that matter.
 

 So let's fix the leak in this great ship to sail high !!
fields.target_audience: It is intended that audience should collect all their memory leak problems.

fields.description_en:
Modifier.Node was announced at Android Dev Summit 2022 to improve the performance of Compose UI.


 In the presentation, it was first explained that the Modifier.Node migration of the Focus modifier has started. Since then, Modifier.Node migrations for various modifiers of Compose UI are underway.


 This session will cover the following topics:
 - Supplementation regarding Compose runtime and explanation about smart composition process
 - Why smart recomposition was not performed for Modifier.composed{} in the original Modifier mechanism. And the motivation behind the development of Modifier.Node and how it will solve this performance problem.
 - Introduction to Modifier.Node API
 - Checking the Modifier of the Compose UI library that has already been migrated while looking at AOSP
 - How to migrate to Modifier.Node an existing custom Modifier or a new Modifier

fields.title_en: The road to release our broadcast feature for YouTube Live
fields.description_en:
Nowadays, the ability to live stream to various platforms is provided by many mobile apps, and millions of people are using it.
 In this session, I will talk about how to implement live streaming for Youtube from an Android app, up until the app release.

Specifically, I will discuss about:
- How to implement live streaming functionnality for Youtube using YouTube Data API
- How to deal with Google's review process when releasing an app with YouTube live streaming functionnality 
and so on, I will explain all the flow and information necessary when you want to develop and release an Android app with live streaming functionnality as of 2023.


 Keywords:
 - YouTube Data API
 - Google OAuth2.0
 - RTMP(s)
 - Multi channel
 - Google Verification

fields.description_en:
In this session, we will talk about how we stopped using the Material 3 design system for Full Jetpack Compose apps and built our own design system.


 The Material 3 design system defines color (colorScheme), typography , and shapes.
 For example, color has primary and onPrimary, and Material 3 components use the colors and shapes from these design systems.


Because it is assumed that the colors defined in Material 3 (such as primary color) are generated from seed color in order to support Dynamic color, they might not match the app's brand colors or there might be no definition of the applicable colors.


 B/43 apps have built their own design system in Compose in order to deal with these problems. The session will show how this was done.

fields.title_en: Securing Android Applications - The not so secret guide explained
fields.title_ja: Securing Android Applications - The not so secret guide explained
fields.description_en:
By making your apps more secure, you help preserve user trust and device integrity.
 

 This talk presents a set of common security issues that Android app developers face:
 - Learn more about how to proactively secure your apps.
 - Understand how to react when one of these issues is discovered in your app.
 

 This talk is based on our new page about risks:
 https://developer.android.com/topic/security/risks
fields.target_audience: Basic knowledge of Android development. People that want to understand in a better how to have basic security development and how to check the security of their application.

fields.description_en:
Gradle Convention Plugins allow us to easily/effectively apply shared configurations across projects a.k.a modules especially for Android developers. Convention plugins have some advantages in build phases much more than shared build scripts. However, we have to implement plugins *correctly* to get the advantages because wrong implementations/configurations may bring negative impacts to Gradle's build features like configuration cache. 
 

 This presentation will explain why Gradle Convention Plugins are good to know for Android developers, and show how to build Gradle plugins from scratch and some plugin examples that collaborate with Android Gradle Plugin.
 

 Keywords: Gradle plugin, convention plugin, build logic, precompiled script plugins
fields.description_ja:

fields.target_audience: Developers who have interests in build speed, Gradle plugin development and flexible project configuration.

fields.title_en: Passkey's showcases and UX issues for various usecases
fields.description_en:
Passkey has attracted much attention as the trump card for a passwordless world in 2022, and more and more services are using it for authentication in 2023.
 The Yahoo! JAPAN ID is aiming for a passwordless world by adding passkey to the various authentication methods without passwords that have been supported up to now.
 dAccount supports passkey as an authentication strength similar to that of line authentication, which can only be realized by a telecommunications carrier, and aims to improve convenience while maintaining security.
 Google is not only in a position to manage passkeys on the Android platform, but can also use them to log into its own accounts.
 MoneyForward ID utilizes a mechanism called Autofill to make the UX similar to using a password manager.
 Mercari has begun supporting passkey to first protect users who use bitcoin-enabled services, even before login use.


 Cross-platform passkey use is also in sight with the announcement that 1Password will launch a passkey management feature in June in addition to its existing password management.


 As various services introduce passkeys for various purposes, the question will shift from "should we adopt passkeys" to "what parts of the services that use passkeys are easy or difficult to use? What are the reasons for the difficulty in using the passkey? Is it the implementation of the service, the browsers and devices support, where to include passkey in the requirements, or if is there any workarounds?", etc. It can be said that we are at the stage of facing more specific issues of UX.


At last year's DroidKaigi, I introduced the history of user authentication methods in the consumer domain and the process starting from the Apple/Google/Microsoft announcement until "Passkey," aka "FIDO authentication made easy to use," which attracted a lot of attention.


This time, I plan to focus on the following four topics:

 -Necessary functionnalities and issues with passkey implementation
 -Specific examples of how that service is implemented
 -Passkey implementation in Android applications
 -Relationship with ID integration


 This presentation shall give you a concrete image of the functions and issues required for passkey implementation, and encourage you to actually design and implement passkeys.

fields.title_en: Introduction to Bytecode Instrumentation with AGP 8
fields.title_ja: Introduction to Bytecode Instrumentation with AGP 8
fields.description_en:
With the introduction of AGP 8, a new API for bytecode manipulation was added to the world of Android build tools. Replacing the previous Transform API, which powered many tools used for everyday development, this new way aims at faster build speed and more flexibility for developers. Popular libraries like Realm have faced challenges to adapt to the new paradigm, but ultimately succeeded in pushing their product to the next stage of evolution.
 

 This talk is the spiritual successor to my session about the now-removed Transform API from DroidKaigi 2019. It will introduce the new methods and classes developers can utilize to instrument their code, presenting the required steps to get started with this powerful set of tools.
fields.target_audience: Attendees are expected to be familiar with the core concepts of Gradle.

fields.title_en: Prevent unintentional cancellation of subscriptions on Android and iOS
fields.description_en:
How to improve churn rate is an important policy topic for subscription-based services. There are two types of subscription churn: voluntary and involuntary.
 Involuntary cancellations occur when a customer's credit card expires. Since originally the customer did not intend to cancel their subscription, they may continue the subscription again if the payment failure situation can be resolved.


 In-app billing supports features such as Grace Period and Account Hold (iOS: Billing retry) to prevent involuntary cancellations. In this session, we will introduce the implementation and measures to prevent involuntary cancellations using Grace Period and Account Hold.


 The session content currently being considered is as follows:


 * In-app subscription purchases
  * Cancellation and types of subscription purchases
 * Introduction to Grace Period / Account Hold
  * The benefit of implementing this feature
  * Functionality differences between iOS and Android
  * Calculating the period of time
 * How to implement and test Grace Period / Account Hold
  * Android implementation
  * iOS implementation
 * Communication with users
  * In-app and out-of-app


 In this session, we will introduce not only Android, but also iOS specifications and implementation. By explaining both platforms, we hope to share our know-how so that you can develop more practical measures.
 In particular, we will touch on the complex subscription cycle and the use of server-side APIs.

fields.title_en: Master of Side-effect in Jetpack Compose
fields.description_en:
Jetpack Compose provides many side-effect handling functions such as LaunchedEffect, SideEffect, DisposableEffect, derivedStateOf, etc. If you use Jetpack Compose, I am sure you have used some of them.
 This session will describe the basic usage of these functions, implementation details, and which function to use for each use case.
fields.description_ja:
Jetpack Compose „Å´„ÅØ LaunchedEffect, SideEffect, DisposableEffect, derivedStateOf, „Å™„Å©„ÅÆÂ§ö„Åè„ÅÆÂâØ‰ΩúÁî®„ÇíÊâ±„ÅÜÈñ¢Êï∞„ÅåÁî®ÊÑè„Åï„Çå„Å¶„Åä„Çä„ÄÅJetpack Compose „Çí‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Å®„Å©„Çå„Åã„ÅØ‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„ÅüÁµåÈ®ì„Åå„ÅÇ„Çã„Å®ÊÄù„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

fields.description_en:
Android volume settings are a feature that varies from device to device. Silent mode in particular varies widely depending on the device. In some cases, you may need to have certain permissions granted to unmute the device. This session will explain what kind of differences exist in how to set the device volume for each device.


 Also, when controlling the volume of Android, it is necessary to use appropriately some attributes (AudioAttributes). I will introduce the different types of AudioAttributes and explain which Audio Attributes should be used in which situations. and which AudioAttributes should be used in which situations. Then, I will explain what you should pay attention to when controlling the volume.


 As you can see, controlling sound in Android is surprisingly complex. In this session, I will talk about how to successfully control sound from the application side.


 - How to change the volume on Android
 - Device differences around volume
 - Silent mode
 - Permissions related to volume control
 - How to use AudioAttributes
 - Things to keep in mind when controlling volume

adb (Android Debug Bridge) is a tool used to communicate with Android devices, and I guess most Android application developers are familiar with it.
 On the other hand, there are few opportunities to learn how adb communicates, the protocol, and the details of the messages sent.
 In this session, I will introduce the implementation of various commands by re-implementing the adb client, digging into how to communicate with the adb server, and the roles and functions of the adb protocol's main message.

List views and swipe tabs are quite common in app development when providing users with a lot of content on a single screen. In many cases, when even more contents are to be provided, you have to put them in a horizontal scroll within the swipe pager, or you have to place a RecyclerView inside a CoordinatorLayout and so on. You often end up in those so-called "nested scrolling" situations. However, when you try to implement these, it may not behave as expected.


 Jetpack Compose supports nested scrolling by default for scrollable components. Therefore, in the former examples above, the parent's swipe may be triggered even though the child's scrolling is supposed to be performed. This can be resolved by implementing NestedScrollConnection appropriately. However, the implementation around nested scrolling is complex and difficult to visualize. In addition, JetpackCompose and AndroidView implement nested scrolling in different ways. Therefore, if you use both of them, you need to propagate the scroll difference properly from Compose to AndroidView side (and vice versa), or it might impair the user experience. I will illustrate this point by looking at the internal implementation of NestedScrollConnection and NestedScrollingParent3 to get an idea.


 This session will mainly focus on nested scrolling in Jetpack Compose, but it will also look back on solutions using NestedScrollView and onInterceptTouchEvent from the AndroidView era. On top of that, I will also demonstrate the differences and how much simpler the code is with Jetpack Compose.


 Through this session, you will achieve the following states.
 - Understand in advance the points to be careful about before implementing nested scrolling in your product development (the problem solving time will fit the planned man-hours)
 - Acquire the thought flow used to investigate the cause when unexpected behavior occurs with nested scrolling during product development.
 - Able to solve the problem of child nested scrolling stuttering depending on the device.


 Table of Contents
 - Nested scrolling problems that may occur in actual product development
 - Solutions in the JetpackCompose Era
 - Comparison with AndroidView era code
 - Interoperability notes
 - * Improvement of performance degradation due to nested scrolling


* Since the code comparison with AndroidView era and interoperability notes part is quite large, I will only talk about the performance improvement if there is enough time.

fields.title_en: No more worries! The guide for handling Don't keep activities in the Compose era
fields.description_en:
Have you ever heard of the term "don't keep activities"? This is the name of an Android developer option that allows you to reproduce a situation where activities other than the one currently being viewed are discarded by the Android OS and its data disappears. If the memory usage of the device is increased while on a screen where the user may stay for a long time, such as a screen with many input forms, there is a possibility that the information entered by the user will be lost. Therefore it may be necessary to guarantee that the behavior is what is expected when this developer option is turned on. Various approaches have been taken to deal with this Don't keep activities option, but now that Compose is beginning to spread, I will sort out old and new methods, and reconsider best practices. In this session, I will talk about the latest approaches to handling Don't keep activities, based on my own experience of dealing with full-Compose apps at work and where I got stuck on this issue.


Planned contents:
- What is "Don't keep activities" in the first place
- How data is lost
- Past approaches and how to respond to don't keep activities in the era of Compose


 Related contents:
- Best practices for saving UI state on Android (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V-s4z7B_Gnc)

fields.title_en: The approach to improve the rate of the push notification acceptance
fields.description_en:
Push notifications are an important feature that allows users to communicate with your users outside of your app. However, the hurdle to get users to opt-in for notifications has been getting higher each year. Android 13 also added Notification Permission, which allows users to choose which notifications they want. This seems to have lowered the notification permission rate for users who install new apps. Furthermore, once the permission is turned off, there are few opportunities to turn it on again, so various measures are required to improve the permission rate.


 In this session, I will share the actual process that we used for analyzing the notification permission acceptance rate in our apps and implementing remedial measures, as well as the results and the improvement cycle of these measures.
 - What is push notification acceptance
  - Behavior of Android 13 and 12 and below
 - Sharing the issue of notification permission
  - Factors that cause it to be turned OFF
  - Number of users who turn it ON
 - Introduction of initiatives to prevent notifications from being turned off
  - Channel support
  - Overview of actual responses
 - Analysis of users
  - Behavior analysis of the users who turn on the permission
  - Hypothesis building
  - Alignment regarding the degree of contribution to the business
 - Implementation of measures
  - Consideration of UI/UX
  - Detailed implementation
 - Effectiveness verification
  - AB test design
  - Permission change


 The discussion will focus not only on improving the permission rate, but also on the process that developers go through to propose and implement measures, and how they are actually implemented and improved. Let's provide a better experience by finding issues and proposing solutions from an engineer's point of view!

fields.title_en: Are you ready? Our code review explained
fields.description_en:
Have you ever been curious to know what kind of code reviews are done outside of your own team?


In our company, we have multiple mobile teams, each with its own development structure and different technologies used.
 In this session, we will introduce the characteristics of code reviews conducted by multiple teams developing Android applications from various perspectives.
We will share tips and know-how to improve code quality and make reviewing more comfortable.


 The contents will include the following:
- How each team conducts code reviews (review flow and tools)
- What they do as a team
- What they do as reviewers/reviewees
- Precautions and tips specific to Android
-  What is going well and what we want to improve in the future

fields.title_en: Material3 Color: Getting started with Jetpack Glance
fields.description_en:
A major feature of Material3 is the color theme that dynamically changes according to user customization, such as the Home screen.
 Jetpack Glance is a library that allows you to implement an App Widget to be displayed on the Home screen using Jetpack Compose.
 By utilizing a dynamic color theme that is highly compatible with the Widget placed on the Home screen, you can provide a more optimized experience to your users.
 In this session, I will explore the basics and usage of Material3 by implementing the Jetpack Glance Theme and Material3 support, which were updated at the same time as Google I/O 2023.

 Summary :
- Basics of AppWidget and RemoteView
- Creating App Widget with Compose using Jetpack Glance
- Basics of Material Design and Material 3
- Support of Material 3 Theme that appeared in Glance beta
- Effective use of Dynamic Color


 There may be some changes or additions to the content if there are updates to the library by the time of the presentation.

fields.title_en: Supercharging Android Testing: Scalable Environments for Large Teams on Diverse Devices & Features
fields.title_ja: Supercharging Android Testing: Scalable Environments for Large Teams on Diverse Devices & Features
fields.description_en:
Unleash the power of Android testing in this talk! Discover strategies for setting up scalable test environments that cater to large teams, diverse devices, and a wide range of features. Revolutionize your testing process and maximize efficiency with reusable setups, deterministic outcomes, and the ability to test and verify A/B tests and more. 
 

 Gain insights into streamlining your testing efforts, ensuring comprehensive coverage, and empowering your team to deliver high-quality Android applications. The talk will also cover best practices for selecting representative test devices, optimizing test coverage, and testing specific features and functionalities prevalent in modern Android applications. By implementing the insights shared in this talk, attendees will be equipped to enhance productivity, streamline testing workflows, and deliver high-quality Android applications to meet the demands of a diverse user base.
fields.target_audience: Attendees should be familiar with basic knowledge of automation testing, this talk will be focused on Android and Espresso. It's aimed to support growing teams, or engineers

fields.title_ja: „Åì„ÅìÊï∞Âπ¥„ÅÆAndroid Text„ÅÆÊñ∞(Ôºü)Ê©üËÉΩ„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶ / What's new (?) in Android Text
fields.description_en:
In the last several years, new features are available in Android text.
 In this session, I'm going to explain what has changed in Android in the framework in the last several years.
 And also I'm going to show useful new APIs and examples added from Android 9 to Android 13.
 Here are the covered topics.
 - Using a custom Latin font and Japanese font in the same TextView. (From Android 9)
 - High performance text animations with TextShaper APIs. (From Android 11)
 - Emoji updatability and what is behind. (From Android 11)
 - Better Japanese line break algorithm. (From Android 13)
 - Faster hyphenation and why it is faster. (From Android 13)
 and more?
 

 I will include not only showing the usage, but also explaining what is happening in the Android OS internals, why it was not possible in the past, etc.

 In the last several years, new features are available in Android text.
 In this session, I'm going to explain what has changed in Android in the framework in the last several years.
 And also I'm going to show useful new APIs and examples added from Android 9 to Android 13.
 Here are the covered topics.
 - Using a custom Latin font and Japanese font in the same TextView. (From Android 9)
 - High performance text animations with TextShaper APIs. (From Android 11)
 - Emoji updatability and what is behind. (From Android 11)
 - Better Japanese line break algorithm. (From Android 13)
 - Faster hyphenation and why it is faster. (From Android 13)
 and more?
 

 I will include not only showing the usage, but also explaining what is happening in the Android OS internals, why it was not possible in the past, etc.

fields.title_en: Android boot verification to ensure integrity of OS and partitions.
fields.title_ja: Android boot verification to ensure integrity of OS and partitions.
fields.description_en:
Being an Android app developer generally Android boot process is remained untouched as we keep focusing on UI/logic/code-quality/themes etc.
 

 It's fun to know how its ensured that Android is booting on a legitimate device and what all procedures are carried out to ensure integrity of each partitions (including oem specific partitions as well).
 

 Android works on devices build by many manufacturers hence its very challenging to perform boot time verifications.
 

 In this talk, I wish to go through background of boot verification, boot flow, rollback protection, use of hashing and cryptographic keys to ensure integrity of each partition etc.
fields.target_audience: Any one who wish to know about booting.

fields.title_en: Leveraging Performance Management Tools: make full use of Firebase Performance Monitoring and Macrobenchmark to introduce Jetpack Compose
fields.description_en:
Overview:
 This session will discuss tackling performance issues in app development, and the introduction of Jetpack Compose as well as the significance of this introduction. Performance is an area that is often put on the back burner compared to crashes and bugs, but this session will show you why it is important and what you can do about it.


 Content Details:


 - This presentation will provide an overview of what Firebase Performance Monitoring is and how to use it.
 - I will also describe Macrobenchmark, a performance-based tool, and how to use it.
 - Examples of how we have actually utilized these tools will be shared. Specifically, I will talk about post-release monitoring in general and how we used these tools during the implementation of Jetpack Compose.


Through the real-life example of our experience with the challenge of introducing Jetpack Compose, I hope to provide attendees useful information on the difficulties of performance management and how we handled them.

fields.title_en: Building a screenshot testing pipeline that scales
fields.title_ja: Building a screenshot testing pipeline that scales
fields.description_en:
Scaling screenshot tests has been a difficult topic on Android for a while. When rigorously visual regression testing design system components or large scale applications, we face issues of scale such as long CI/CD run times, increased costs or a reduction of productivity due to conflicting pull requests.
 

 This talk will go through some of the tradeoffs being made and proposes a screenshot testing pipeline that combines paparazzi to generate screenshots with reg-suit to create a diffing report in a GCS bucket.
fields.target_audience: Android engineers that want to confidently do large scale UI changes. Platform engineers that want to provide visual regression testing tooling to their co-workers. Android Engineers interested in issues of organisational scale.
fields.message_ja: This session room has been changed from Dolphin to Chipmunk.

fields.description_en:
Content sharing between apps via intents is a widely used feature in all kinds of apps. Share intents have been around since the first versions of Android and continue to be an important area of functionality, with the latest version Android 14 adding more functionalities to it as well.
 This session will provide a comprehensive review of sharing functionality and best practices for both the sharer (sender) and receiver.
Main topics will include how to use intents, handling various data types, managing permissions, customizing the share sheet, sharing shortcuts and related features. (If sharing alone is not enough for 40 minutes, other topics may be included).

fields.title_en: (Unofficial) Guide to App Architecture Guide Vol. 2
fields.title_ja: (Unofficial) Guide to App Architecture Guide Vol. 2
fields.description_en:
We have been publishing the Android App Architecture Guide since 2021 and continue to add new content daily. However, we often find important aspects of the design that have not yet been explained. This time, as a continuation of last year's guide, I would like to talk about the parts that have not been covered in the official guide.
 * Dependency Injection
  - Why you should use Dagger Hilt
  - Flaws of Dagger Hilt
  - What are the alternatives to Dagger Hilt
 * Multi-module
  - Why and when is the best time to separate modules
  - How should we actually separate modules
  - 9 anti-patterns encountered in the process of modularization and their solutions

fields.title_en: Jetpack Benchmark and where to find them
fields.title_ja: Jetpack Benchmark and where to find them
fields.description_en:
Performance is a key consideration for any mobile app, and it's critical to ensure that your app is fast and responsive in order to provide a great user experience. But how do you measure performance, and how do you ensure that your app is meeting your performance goals? That's where the Jetpack benchmark library comes in.
 

 In this talk, I'll be discussing the Jetpack benchmark library and exploring how it can help you measure and optimize the performance of your Android app. I'll cover the basics of benchmarking, including how to define benchmarks, how to run them, and how to analyze the results. I'll also explore some of the advanced features of the Jetpack benchmark library, such as how to set up custom benchmarking environments and how to use the library with other performance analysis tools.
 

 But that's just the beginning - I'll also share some real-world examples of how the Jetpack benchmark library has helped developers optimize their apps for better performance. And, of course, I'll offer some tips and best practices for using the library effectively in your own apps.
 

 Whether you're a seasoned Android developer or just starting out, this talk is for you. By the end of it, you'll have a solid understanding of the Jetpack benchmark library and be equipped with the knowledge you need to optimize the performance of your own apps. Join me for an engaging and informative discussion on this critical aspect of mobile app development!
fields.target_audience: Basic understanding of Android and testing.

fields.title_en: Maintaining E2E Test Automation as We Transition from View to Compose
fields.title_ja: Maintaining E2E Test Automation as We Transition from View to Compose
fields.description_en:
In projects that have regular releases at short intervals, regression testing is also performed frequently.
 The larger the project, the more time it takes to conduct these tests. Thus, test automation is key in continuing to ship releases. However, there are numerous pitfalls in implementing tests, such as not being able to test some OS functions or functions dependent on third-party vendor SDKs, and test targets being difficult to locate in the Compose tree structure, even if the tests are possible.
 

 In this session, using Mercari's payment-related features as a case-study, we will cover
 - How to work with the QA team to automate regression testing
 - How to write tests as you transition from View to Compose
 - Using TestTags effectively
 and other insights gained while facing these pitfalls during development.
fields.target_audience:
- Development teams that want to help with speed up QA regression testing
- Developers who want to know about writing tests for Compose
- Developers who are interested in E2E testing

fields.description_en:
Text Field is one of the basic components, but it is not easy to master. This session will cover Compose's Text Field API and the BasicTextField2 API currently under development.


 Specifically, the following topics will be covered:
- Explanation about each parameter of BasicTextField / TextField API and how to use them
- How to create a custom designed Text Field using BasicTextField
- How to use BasicTextField to create a special Text Field such as an authentication code input box
- A (partial) solution to the problem of text jumping when Japanese characters are entered
- Best practices for managing Text Field states
- Why develop a new Text Field API
- Introduction and future prospects of BasicTextField2 API currently under development

fields.title_en: MVI-based State Machines architecture with KMM and Jetpack
fields.description_en:
We have been interested in Kotlin Multiplatform (KMM) for years as potentially the next big cross-platform technology, and we have been implementing it in projects since before the Alpha version was released around 2020. Shortly after that, Jetpack Compose and SwiftUI came out, so we began researching architectures that would successfully combine these three technologies. As a result, we found that since Jetpack Compose and SwiftUI are declarative UI frameworks, an MVI-based architecture works very well with them.


 In this session, we would like to share our experience of using MVI and these three technologies in actual development. First, we will introduce the features of MVI and explain why we chose this architecture compared to other UI architectures (MVVM, MVP). Next, we will show you the simplest implementation of MVI and demonstrate how to apply the StateMachine architecture to make it easier to use. Finally, we will explain the knowledge gained from the real project implementation, and the benefits of team development.


 Table of Contents (planned):
 - Introduction to KMM, Jetpack Compose and SwiftUI
 - MVI Architecture
  - Why use MVI
  - How to implement MVI
  - How to use with Jetpack Compose / SwiftUI
 - StateMachine based on MVI architecture
  - State Safety
  - State UML Diagrams
  - StateMachine implementation
 - Actual project implementation
  - Usage with Jetpack Compose / SwiftUI
  - Benefits of Team Development

fields.title_en: Learn the mechanism of Android's hardware control through GPIO control
fields.description_en:
In order to use a microcontroller with AndroidOS to operate devices connected to the microcontroller, GPIO control is required.


 However, with the end of AndroidThings development, it has become difficult to easily operate GPIO on Android, and there is little information on the Internet that covers how to operate GPIO on pure Android OS.


 In this session, using the TinkerBoard2S microcomputer as an example, I will introduce how to operate GPIO from an Android application, explaining the appropriate permissions when operating hardware from an Android application, and the advantages and disadvantages of each of the following methods.


- Setting the same SharedUserId as the privileged application by performing platform signing, to grant the same privileges as the privileged application.
- Separating as services the parts that require permissions from the application, to achieve the principle of least privilege.
- Improving the security of the implementation from a platform architecture point of view by not granting permissions to the application layer.


 Through these demonstrations, I will explain how Android-based devices operate hardware and what implementation methods are suitable depending on the scale of development.

Do you properly implement contentDescription? This is an accessibility-related functionality that you see when implementing UI. Now that the mainstream of UI is shifting from Android View to Compose, many of you may be aware of this functionality, due to the fact some Composables require you to set a contentDescription.

 There is no doubt that development should be done with sufficient accessibility consideration right from the start. In reality, however, I suspect that there are many situations where it is difficult to take action at a later date. You will get told: "It's been years since the app was released, we haven't heard any complaints and we have other business priorities, so we'll do that another time."


 This session will cover a series of processes from planning to implementation of measures to improve accessibility. In the first half, I will aim to put accessibility measures at the top of the product backlog and broaden our perspective on accessibility.

 In the latter half, in order to get a concrete image of these measures, I will show good/bad examples from an accessibility perspective, along with sample code for both Android View and Compose. I will also introduce some useful tools for smoother development.


 Don't you shudder to think that some of the services you provide might have screen transitions that some users can never do? Accessibility tends to be understood as "for the visually impaired," but the scope of accessibility is actually much broader: the focus is to provide the same ease of use for all users. Therefore, there are many ways to improve accessibility. I hope this session will help you take the first step toward improving accessibility.

fields.title_en: Deep dive into size configuration changes
fields.title_ja: Deep dive into size configuration changes
fields.description_en:
Some of you may be unfamiliar with the words "configuration change". Android actually allows you to change the configuration of the device while the application is running. For example, changing the orientation of the screen, the language/region, switching between dark and light modes, etc. all of those are configuration changes.


 Changing the window size is also a configuration change. In this session, I will discuss about some interesting and sometimes troublesome features of size-related configuration changes. Starting with how to correctly calculate the window size of an app, we will also discuss the edge cases that need to be considered and the different approaches to handling size-related configuration changes. Also, configuration changes do not always re-create activities. I will also explain when an activity is re-created and when it is not.


 This session will cover what you will be facing when your app supports devices such as tablets and foldable devices. It is also useful for those who are considering making their apps multi-window compatible.

fields.title_en: What makes good unit testing for Android apps?
fields.description_en:
Unit testing is used by many Android application developers. Android Developers (the official documentation for Android developers) is also well documented on automated testing, so the environment for starting to write tests is well prepared.
 On the other hand, when you start writing tests, you may face a situation where you wonder what kind of test is suitable for your application. Or after having written tests, you may run into the problem that it doesn't feel cost-effective.
 If we assume that a good unit test is an appropriate or cost-effective unit test, then implementing a good unit test is more difficult than mastering the testing libraries and frameworks.


 In this session, I will summarize about what a good unit test is, how to improve them so they become good unit tests, based on the Android Developers' testing documents, books, and my own experience of implementing and reviewing test code for Android applications.


 Specifically, the following topics will be introduced:


- Types of automated testing in Android applications
-  What is a good unit test
 - Advantages and disadvantages of test double
 - Improving the readability of test code
 - Improving the product code to make it a good unit test

fields.title_en: Rich UI implementation examples using Jetpack Compose
fields.description_en:
With the advent of Jetpack Compose, it has become easier to achieve powerful UI expressions such as animation with a small amount of code.
 However, without a concrete image of how to use them, it may be difficult to implement them in actual products.
 This session will introduce an overview of powerful UI expression techniques that can be realized with Jetpack Compose and some examples of implementation using these techniques, aiming to give you an idea of how to use them in your everyday products.


 This session aims to provide knowledge not only for Android engineers, but also for designers who are actually thinking about UI expression methods.


 The following contents are planned


 # Rich UI expression techniques
 - Text and image decoration
 - Brushes
 - Animation
 - High API functions (RenderEffect,AGSL)
 # Actual examples
 - Coachmark implementation
 - List animation
 - Make any UI stand out
 etc.

fields.title_en: N-examples of how to implement with Jetpack Compose those UIs you often see
fields.description_en:
Have you ever experienced something like this?
 A "I want to convert this screen to Jetpack Compose.
 B "How long will it take?"
 A "First, I need to do some research ......"
 B "How long will the research take?"
 A "It will be fast if I can find references right away, but...... I need to search how to implement each UI and add up the man-hours. ......
 B "Then why don't we prioritize other tasks that we can already estimate?"
 A "......"


 I've researched that!
So I will introduce as many specific implementation methods and precautions for common UI as time permits.
 We'll see how many I can present. For example, I am considering introducing the followings:
 Carousel / Loading / In-page link / "More" button / Search UI / Bottom sheet / Credit card number input / Infinite pager / Bottom tab / Speech Bubble / List-to-details zoom animation / First launch walkthrough / Accordion


 You might find it difficult to find the right information for your purpose from a large amount of documents, and how even if you do find repositories that may be helpful, you can't know if it really matches your image until you clone and build them. So this session will solve these problems by introducing implementation methods along with screenshots and videos.

fields.title_en: Introduction to performance improvement by monitoring
fields.description_en:
"Slow application startup time" and "Poor screen transition timing" are issues that have always plagued engineers...


 The presenter will talk about how to find and improve the weak points while monitoring performance using Performance, Android Vitals, Firebase Performance Monitoring, JankStats, etc., based on actual cases he has done.

fields.title_en: How to implement In-app billing on Flutter ‚Äì the road to unify Android/iOS logics
fields.description_en:
In this presentation, I will introduce the points I struggled with, kept in mind or learned while porting from Android to Flutter the existing in-app billing functionality of an app available on the market.


 Since its launch in 2018, Flutter has established itself as a cross-platform framework.
 The product I was involved in also realized the transition from the dual Android/iOS native app development system to a cross-platform development system using Flutter.
 The unification of various functions and UI was realized thanks to Flutter.


 However, an annoying part about cross-platform development is when sometimes branching Android/iOS (I'd like to include Web as well) is inevitable due to circumstances of either side.
 For some UIs, it will be necessary to consider the impact on users of each OS, and branch implementations using adaptive UIs after consulting with designers.


 "Branching the implementation of in-app payment integration with each store" is one of the first concerns that comes to mind for those with such implementation experience.
 How do you handle the processing of what is only required for Android, or on the contrary, only for iOS? In particular, how should we absorb differences on the platform side, such as subscription plan changes?


 Fortunately, the development of libraries that wrap the processing for both operating systems are underway and open to the public as OSS.
 In this presentation, based on my experience of implementing in-app billing using such library, I will mainly explain how to migrate PlayStore-specific implementations to Flutter, and also other various topics such as what you need to keep in mind when developing cross-platform apps.



 The contents of this presentation are planned as follow.


 - Introduction of the library used
  - Internal implementation explanation
  - Compatibility with Android native API
 - Implementations Flow
  - Purchase
  - Restore Purchase
  - Subscription Plan Change
 - Receiving Purchase Results

fields.title_en: Overcoming the Challenges of Integrating an Epub Viewer into a Modern Android App
fields.title_ja: Overcoming the Challenges of Integrating an Epub Viewer into a Modern Android App
fields.description_en:
Epub is an open standard, digital publication format that is used to distribute electronic books. It is a popular format for ebooks, and it is supported by a wide range of devices, including e-readers, tablets, and smartphones. It might be the best solution if you want to implement a Book Viewer in Android APP.  
 

 In a Modern Android app, developers can use AndroidView in Compose to display an Epub viewer from an Epub SDK. However, there are a few challenges that developers face when trying to integrate an Epub viewer into an Android app. 
 

 In this talk, I will explain how to implement a modern Android structure for importing an Epub viewer and my experience about how to overcome challenges as 
 * Avoiding recomposition of AndroidView
 * Interact with composable above it (such as controller, table of contents..) 
 * Handling data flow
 * Other issues
fields.target_audience:
* Developers who want to develop Epub viewers
* Developers who want to develop AndroidView in Compose
* Developers who have developed AndroidView in Compose beforehand
* Developers who want to learn how to handle both AndroidView and Compose

fields.title_en: The world of Android Enterprise ‚Äì what you should know when develop enterprise apps
fields.description_en:
Have you ever imagined what kind of devices/environments business applications are installed on in companies or organizations?
 Companies and organizations sometimes distribute work devices to their employees, or allow employees to use their private devices for work as BYOD (Bring Your Own Device).
 In this case, operating the device as it is poses various risks in terms of security, privacy, and labor health. For example, should employees be free to install apps on a company-issued device without going through the Google Play Store? Can you really say that the employee's privacy is protected when there are work apps running on their personal devices?
 The mechanism to secure devices against these risks is MDM (Mobile Device Management), which is provided by Android Enterprise.
 That is to say, many business apps may run in this MDM environment.


 This session will introduce how Android Enterprise works to support the business use of Android, and the possible approaches that business app developers can take to Android Enterprise.
 Specifically, I will introduce how MDM works in Android Enterprise, how it affects business apps, and the special features that business apps can provide in an MDM environment, based on publicly available information on Android Enterprise.
 Through this session, I aim to provide business app developers a deeper understanding of the end-user environment.


 Keywords: Android Enterprise, MDM, Work Profile, BYOD, BtoB, Managed Configurations

fields.title_en: Make NFC app development easy by using Host-based card emulation
fields.description_en:
Near Field Communication (NFC) is a wireless communication technology that allows two devices to send and receive data over a very short distance. The main application is for card readers to read information from NFC tags and cards.


 Android has supported NFC reading since version 2.3 (API Level 9). Host-based card emulation (HCE) has also been introduced since version 4.4 (API Level 19).


 With HCE, not only can the Android device read the card, but the Android device itself can act as an NFC card.
 Using the Android device as a card, various services and applications can be realized by communicating with other devices and NFC readers.


 And while smartcars typically have limited capabilities, HCE turns an Android device into a smartcard with a display, a camera and an advanced fingerprint reader. By leveraging HCE, you can boost the apeal of your services and apps.


 This session will cover the basics of using HCE to make an Android device function as a smart card. Various standards that support smart cards will also be explained.
 Finally, I also hope to share some of the traps I went through while actually implementing smart cards with HCE.

fields.title_en: Unleashing the Power of Android Studio
fields.title_ja: Unleashing the Power of Android Studio
fields.description_en:
Unleash the true power of Android Studio you never knew existed, and discover helpful features that will solve your app development problems!


 Today's app development is undergoing new changes with the advent of Jetpack Compose. On the other hand, by working with a combination of many technologies, a lot of people may find it difficult to develop efficiently and keep up with changes.
 In this session, I will introduce debugging and productivity techniques using the latest features of Android Studio.
 The session will also touch on features and techniques to improve individual developer productivity and accelerate team development, so it is intended for a wide range of developers from beginners to those using AndroidStudio at work.


  - Introduction to the latest features of Android Studio to improve programming productivity
  - Debugging techniques for bug-free application development
  - Tools leveraging to achieve both good performance and quality
  - Project and IDE operation techniques to facilitate team development


 This session will use the latest version of Android Studio at the time of the presentation (It is Android Studio Hedgehog at the time of the session submission, but a newer version may be used by then).
Masahiro Hidaka, who is a DroidKaigi Organizer, will give a message to all attendees for DroidKaigi 2023.

Worried about your career? We will have engineers with various backgrounds as panelists to reply to your questions. They can consult you not only on organization related matters like evaluation and reward systems, but also on more personal topics such as childcare, work-life balance and skill improvement. Would you like to think about your worries together with the community? You can also post questions anonymously, so please feel free to join us.
We will provide lunch box on both dates of the conference
fields.description_ja: We will provide lunch box on both dates of the conference

fields.description_en: We will be organizing office tours of sponsor companies for scholarship program attendees. We will inform you of the details. Stay tuned!
Masahiro Hidaka, who is a DroidKaigi Organizer, will give a message to all attendees for DroidKaigi 2023.
fields.description_ja: Masahiro Hidaka, who is a DroidKaigi Organizer, will give a message to all attendees for DroidKaigi 2023.

fields.description_en:
We plan to organize several meetups about different topics. Here are the topics for Day.3 meetups:

- 12:00‚Äì13:20ÔºöAndroid-related technologies (Architecture, Jetpack Compose, any technology is welcome!)
- 15:00‚Äì16:00ÔºöYour DroidKaigi 2023 memories

Come talk with us and other attendees over lunch and/or snacks!

- Only limited seats are available, so please arrive early to the meeting point if you would like to join.
- For lunch-time meetups, you will need to go get your lunch box before showing up to the meetup.
- We will also have meetups on Day.1 and Day.2 with different topics. Look for updates on Medium for further updates.

Codelabs
DroidKaigi staff will recommend some codelabs from the official Google Codelabs. You can set up the codelab environment at the venue and get started there. Come join us and enjoy doing codelabs with other attendees and/or staff, and get a chance to learn about a wide range of technical topics!

- We will prepare the internet connection for the codelab and other events on Day.3.
- For a smoother experience, please have the latest version of Android Studio (Giraffe) installed before Day.3.


Barista Coffee
Talk with other attendees around a delicious cup of coffee! Baristas from the Alpha Betti Cafe who brought us great coffee at DroidKaigi 2018 and 2019 will join us once again! Both hot and iced coffee will be served.
(Coffee will also be served on Day.1 and Day.2 as well!)
We will provide lunch box on both dates of the conference

We will also hold small group sessions with the panelists of the Career Panel Discussion. Don't hesitate to ask more personal worries. The panelists may give you further/specific advice or help you see your situation from a different perspective.

- You do not need to have attended the Career Panel Discussion first, everyone is welcome.
- We are arranging for a reservation system, and we will inform you how to reserve a seat via X, emails and the official website later.
Join us and enjoy delicious meals, drinks, and communication with speakers and attendees!
